TEXT: The applicant is a NORP citizen and sole heir and administrator of the estate of the late PERSON . She is represented before the Court by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

According to the applicant , PERSON and his siblings , plaintiffs in action No . CARDINAL in ORG , became the registered owners of CARDINAL properties situated at GPE in the village of GPE , after a local enquiry of ORG for the purpose of widening a street , and after the death of the GPE mother , PERSON , on CARDINAL SeptemberCARDINAL .
Before that date the properties had been registered in the name of PERSON who had inherited it from his sister , PERSON , to whom the properties had been donated by their parents .

In DATE a certain PERSON filed action No . CARDINAL in the GPE ORG claiming that she and her husband , PERSON , were the owners of the properties by purchase and/or by long uninterrupted adverse possession .

On DATE the court made an order for a substituted service of the writ of summons on PERSON by publication of the writ in the newspaper the “ FAC ” , by posting a copy of the writ at CARDINAL coffee - shops in the village GPE ( where the properties were situated ) , by serving it upon a certain NORP PERSON of GPE and by posting a copy on the court ’s notice board .
PERSON and his siblings failed to enter a notice of appearance and , when the action was fixed for hearing , the case was dealt with in their absence .

Having heard the evidence of the witnesses , ORG was satisfied that PERSON had been in possession of the CARDINAL properties for more than the prescribed period , adversely , peacefully and uninterruptedly . On DATE the court ordered the cancellation of the registration of the properties in the name of PERSON and their registration in the name of PERSON , who subsequently had the plots registered in the name of his daughters by donation . Thereafter , one of the daughters mortgaged the properties in favour of ORG The writ of summons in action No . CARDINAL was never served on the plaintiffs who were at all times residents of GPE or GPE and whose address was unknown . They all had , however , a representative in GPE , Mr PERSON .

In DATE PERSON retired to GPE . When he discovered that the registration of the properties had been cancelled , he lodged action No . CARDINAL on DATE with ORG in order to have the judgment in action No . CARDINAL/CARDINAL set aside . He was joined in this action by his siblings . They maintained that the judgment had been obtained by fraud and that there had been a breach of the procedural rules concerning the summons to appear . They alleged that they should have been personally notified of the writ of summons .

On DATE ORG dismissed the action , referring extensively to NORP and NORP case - law on the matter . It held that , in deciding action No . CARDINAL , ORG had issued an order according to which the notification of the writ of summons was to take place by its publication in the “ ORG ” newspaper and a copy of it placed on the notice - boards of CARDINAL coffee - shops in the village of GPE , as well as that of ORG of GPE . In exercising its discretionary powers , ORG considered that such a notification was effective as the plaintiffs , whose nationality and address were unknown to the court , were abroad and the relevant documents , which had been sent to them by CARDINAL of their relatives , were returned undelivered . It concluded that , although this method of notification was not wholly efficient , it was important for citizens who had had their rights recognised by a court decision to be able to rely on such a decision .

In particular , as to the allegation that the default judgment was obtained by fraud , the court found that the plaintiffs had failed to prove the existence of any such fraud . As to the allegation that there had been a procedural irregularity in that a notice of a writ of summons instead of the writ of summons itself should have been served upon them , being non - Cypriots , the court held that such an irregularity would result in the annulment of the judgment ex debito justitiae . However , the court concluded that PERSON and his siblings had failed to produce evidence to establish that they were not NORP nationals .

The plaintiffs appealed to ORG which dismissed the appeal on DATE . ORG adopted the conclusions of ORG . It further observed that any procedural irregularity , which would have led to the proceedings in action CARDINAL being annulled , had become a “ mere irregularity ” by reason of the new LAW which was published on DATE and which ( in accordance with the case - law that followed ) had retrospective effect . This observation related only to the alleged irregularity that was brought about by the issue of the writ of summons instead of the issue of a notice of the writ . In any event , ORG dismissed the submission that there had been an irregularity with respect to the service of the writ , as PERSON and his siblings had failed to prove that they were non - Cypriots .
Finally , ORG held :

“ However , the respondents could submit to the ORG an application in action CARDINAL for setting aside [ the judgment ] , explaining the default of appearance as well as why such a period of time has passed until they took such a step [ filing the application ] and giving grounds for a prima facie case , so as to enable the ORG to exercise its discretionary power … The respondents did not follow such a course and no such issue was raised for determination . ”
Order CARDINAL , Rule CARDINAL of ORG reads as follows :
“ No writ of summons for service out of GPE of which notice is to be given out of GPE , shall be sealed without the leave of the ORG or a Judge . ”
Order CARDINAL , Rule CARDINAL of ORG provides as follows :

“ Any judgment by default , whether under this Order or under any other of these rules , may in a proper case be set aside by the ORG upon such terms as to costs or otherwise as the ORG may think fit . ”

Domestic case - law has made it clear that the primary consideration for the court of review is whether the defendant ’s case has merits to which heed should be paid ( PERSON v. ORG , [ DATE ] ORG CARDINAL ) .
More recent authorities have reiterated the principle as follows :

“ The effect of the case - law is that the court must not hasten to deprive a party of his right to be heard in his case , so long as he discloses merits . But the court may , nevertheless , decline to re - open the case if his conduct is such as to strike at the root of the administration of justice . Where the conduct of the party applying to set aside a judgment is inexcusable , contumacious , to the extent of grossly disregarding the judicial process or the rights of his adversary , the court may , in its discretion , refuse to set aside the judgment . ” ( NORP v. PERSON [ DATE ] CARDINAL CLR CARDINAL ) .

The Government stress that , in the context of an application to set aside a default judgment , the defendant does not have to show that he has not been personally notified of the proceedings in which the default judgment was delivered . He is only required to explain why he failed to appear in order to show that his non - appearance was not the result of any gross disregard for the judicial process .
